Package thirdparty.net.oelen.polsolve.jt

Class RPoly

java.lang.Object
thirdparty.net.oelen.polsolve.jt.RPoly
public class RPoly extends Object

Represents a polynomial equation of the form p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + ... where A, B, C, etc are real coefficients.

Includes a method for finding the zeros of a real polynomial by a specialized version of the algorithm of Jenkins and Traub, developed especially for poly- nomials with real coefficients. This specialized method is approximately 3 times as fast as the general algorithm when applied to the same polynomial. Like the general algorithm, the specialized method finds the zeros one at a time in roughly increasing order of modulus and deflates the polynomial to one of lower degree.

Zero finder ported from FORTRAN version of algorithm 493 courtesy Netlib Repository.

This class is not thread-safe.

Modified by: Wilco Oelen

Version:
October 6, 2015
Author:
Wilco Oelen

  • Constructor Details

    • RPoly

      public RPoly(double[] coef)
      Constructor of the polynomial, with the coefficients given as an array of doubles.
      Parameters:
      coef - The coefficients of the polynomial in the order of the constant term to the term with the highest power, i.e. the polynomial is coef[0] + coef[1]*x + coef[2]*x^2 ... coef[N]*x^N, where N+1 is the length of the supplied array. Element coef[N] must be non-zero!

  • Method Details

    • eval

      public double eval(double x)
      Evaluates the polynomial at the given double argument.
      Parameters:
      x - The real value for which the polynomial must be evaluated. The result is a real value.
      Returns:
      The value of the polynomial, evaluated at the given argument.

    • eval

      public double[] eval(double xre, double xim)
      Evaluates the polynomial at the given complex argument.
      Parameters:
      xre - The real part of the argument at which the polynomial is evaluated.
      xim - The imaginary part of the argument at which the polynomial is evaluated.
      Returns:
      A double array, which contains the complex value of the polynomial, evaluated at the given argument. The returned array contains two real values. The value at index 0 is the real part of the return value and the value at index 1 is the imaginary part of the return value.

    • eval

      public void eval(double[] result, double xre, double xim)
      Evaluates the polynomial at the given complex argument. This is like the other eval() method, but in this one the result of the evaluation is put in an array, which already is allocated in the calling environment. This method allows many evaluations of the polynomial without the need to allocate many small 2-element arrays for storing the result.
      Parameters:
      result - A double-array with at least two elements, in which the result of the evaluation is stored. The value at index 0 is replaced by the real part of the polynomial value and the value at index 1 is replaced by the imaginary part of the polynomial value. If the supplied array contains more than 2 elements, then the elements with index 2 or larger are not touched at all.
      xre - The real part of the argument at which the polynomial is evaluated.
      xim - The imaginary part of the argument at which the polynomial is evaluated.

    • eval_deriv

      public void eval_deriv(double[] result, double[] dresult, double xre, double xim)
      Evaluates the polynomial and the derivative of the polynomial simultaneously for the given value of x.
      Parameters:
      result - A double-array with at least two elements, in which the result of the evaluation is stored. The value at index 0 is replaced by the real part of the polynomial value and the value at index 1 is replaced by the imaginary part of the polynomial value. If the supplied array contains more than 2 elements, then the elements with index 2 or larger are not touched at all.
      dresult - A double-array with at least two elements, in which the result of the evaluation is stored. The value at index 0 is replaced by the real part of the derivative value and the value at index 1 is replaced by the imaginary part of the derivative value. If the supplied array contains more than 2 elements, then the elements with index 2 or larger are not touched at all.
      xre - The real part of the argument at which the derivative is evaluated.
      xim - The imaginary part of the argument at which the derivative is evaluated.

    • solve

      public int solve(double[] zeror, double[] zeroi)
      This method computes the roots of the polynomial and stores the roots in preallocated arrays, which are passed as arguments.
      Parameters:
      zeror - Array, in which the real parts of the zeros will be stored after computation of the zeros. This array must have a length of at least N elements, where N is the degree of the polynomial.
      zeroi - Array, in which the imaginary parts of the zeros will be stored after computation of the zeros. This array must have a length of at least N elements, where N is the degree of the polynomial.
      Returns:
      Returns the degree of the polynomial if the computation succeeds, and returns a value less than the degree of the polynomial if an error occurs (e.g. convergence failure). When a value less than the degree of the polynomial is returned, then only part (or none) of the roots could be determined.
